content.title: Why Planck Units Matter
content.summary: Planck units are not just a convenient system of measurement—they mark the scales where our current understanding of physics breaks down and quantum gravity becomes essential. They define the ultimate limits of measurability in the universe.

key_reasons.explanation: Planck units are the only scales constructible from c, ℏ, and G without arbitrary choices. They don't depend on any particular particle or material.
key_reasons.significance: Nature provides these scales; we merely discover them

key_reasons.explanation: At Planck scales, both quantum effects (ℏ) and gravitational effects (G) become equally important. Our separate theories of QM and GR must merge.
key_reasons.significance: Defines where we need new physics

key_reasons.explanation: Cannot measure distances < ℓ_P, times < t_P, or temperatures > T_P. Attempting to do so creates black holes or other quantum gravitational objects.
key_reasons.significance: Fundamental limits on knowledge, not just technology

key_reasons.explanation: The early universe at t < t_P was in the Planck epoch where quantum gravity dominated. Understanding the Big Bang requires understanding Planck physics.
Planck mass m_P ≈ 10¹⁹ GeV sets the scale of quantum gravity. All known particles are vastly lighter—explaining this hierarchy is a central problem.

common_misconceptions.misconception: Planck units are just another unit system like metric or imperial
common_misconceptions.correction: Planck units are derived from fundamental constants, not arbitrary standards. They have physical significance.

common_misconceptions.misconception: We will eventually probe Planck scales with better technology
common_misconceptions.correction: The issue isn't technology—it's fundamental limits from quantum mechanics and gravity. Building a 'Planck accelerator' would require energy > 10¹⁹ GeV.

common_misconceptions.misconception: Planck scales are just very small and not relevant to us
common_misconceptions.correction: Planck physics determines cosmic structure, black hole physics, and potentially the consistency of our entire physical framework.

applications: Quantum gravity research (string theory, LQG, etc.)
Fundamental limits on computation and measurement

quote.text: These quantities retain their natural significance as long as the laws of gravitation, of the propagation of light in a vacuum, and the two principles of thermodynamics remain valid; they must therefore, when measured by the most diverse intelligences using the most varied methods, always yield the same values.
